data.title: Having Trouble Compiling a module .dll
data.body:
After cloning the master branch of godot yesterday (9/30/17) and building the engine for windows I tried going through the module tutorial. I was able to statically build and use the 'sumator' module (as in the tuorial) without problems, however, when trying to build a dll version of the module through VS2015, I get these error messages:

```
Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	LNK1181	cannot open input file 'sumator.windows.tools.32.windows.tools.32.lib'	godot	F:\godot\LINK	1	

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	MSB3073	The command "echo Starting SCons && cmd /V /C set "plat=x86" ^& (if "x86"=="x64" (set "plat=x86_amd64")) ^& set "tools=yes" ^& (if "debug"=="release" (set "tools=no")) ^& call "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\vcvarsall.bat" !plat! ^& scons platform=windows target=debug tools=!tools! -j1" exited with code 2.	godot	C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\Microsoft.Cpp\v4.0\V140\Microsoft.MakeFile.Targets	41	
```
The only file that changed between my successful build of static module and this one was the SCsub file which was setup like the tutorial:

```
Import('env')

sources = [
    "register_types.cpp",
    "sumator.cpp"
]

module_env = env.Clone()
module_env.Append(CXXFLAGS='-fPIC')  # Needed to compile shared library
module_env['LIBS'] = []

shared_lib = module_env.SharedLibrary(target='#bin/sumator', source=sources)

shared_lib_shim = shared_lib[0].name.rsplit('.', 1)[0]
env.Append(LIBS=[shared_lib_shim])
env.Append(LIBPATH=['#bin'])
```

I know some of the tutorials are becoming dated with version 3.0, so is there something wrong with the file above or is there something else I need to do to get a .dll to show up in the bin folder?

data.title: Disable the viewport camera's interpolation when switching scene tabs
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version**
Linux Mint 18.2 Cinnamon x64, Godot master c9a925c

**Issue description:**
Each open scene tab will remember the position/rotation data of the viewport camera when switching to another tab, and re-apply it when switching back. When this happens, the movement to the new transform is interpolated, which doesn't make much sense and can be a little nauseating when switching between tabs often. It should really just 'jump' to the destination.

This is similar to #11008, but unlike what is stated there, it actually does happen when switching to already opened scenes (as shown in the video below).

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new scene or two
2. Move the camera around in each scene 
3. Switch between the scene tabs
4. [Vomit](https://streamable.com/1gj0p)

data.title: Freelook WASD doesn't override Animation panel hotkeys
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version**
Linux Mint 18.2 Cinnamon x64, Godot master c9a925c

**Issue description:**
When using freelook with the Animation panel open, the WASD keys will interact with it and cause the loaded animation to start/stop playback, or even play in reverse. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create/open an animation via the AnimationPlayer node
2. With the Animation panel open, navigate around using Freelook

data.title: [Suggestion] - Borderless fullscreen feature?
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
2.1.4

![](https://i.gyazo.com/7e0c73441ca84a87a231c9458673a1d7.png)


You can do:
`OS.set_window_maximized(true)`, and then `OS.set_borderless_window(true)` however... the windows taskbar is still on top.

Which Zylann said is legal behavior, so my suggestion is the ability to hide the taskbar, or if possible.. make godot fullscreen and render the main OS display as well.

Regular fullscreen works, but when you alt-tab out of it, it flickers black (leaving the gpu to OS). My suggestion is the ability to render both the game in fullscreen and the OS display, so when a person alt-tabs it's a seamless transition. 

Path of Exile has this [here](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/i5l97ZTM1x8/maxresdefault.jpg), see how it's windowed fullscreen, but no borders?

data.title: Leak when reference member property is part of binary operation
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 17.04 64bit, master c9a925c

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

If the property `TextureRect.texture` is part of an binary operation, the `ImageTexture` instance will leak:

```
WARNING: cleanup: ObjectDB Instances still exist!
At: core/object.cpp:1858.
Leaked Instance: ImageTexture:930 - Resource Name:  Path: 
Orphan StringName: ImageTexture
StringName: 1 unclaimed string names at exit.
```

**Steps to reproduce:**

Commenting both asserts fixes it:

```
extends TextureRect

func _ready():
    var imageTexture = ImageTexture.new()
    var dynImage = Image.new()

    dynImage.create(256,256,false,Image.FORMAT_RGB8)
    dynImage.fill(Color(1,0,0,1))

    imageTexture.create_from_image(dynImage)
    self.texture = imageTexture
    
    # if self.texture is part of a binary operation, the leak happens
    assert(self.texture != null)
    #assert(self.texture == imageTexture)
```

data.title: 2D and Viewport stretch modes fail on Windows fullscreen with desktop display scaling
data.body:
Windows 10 64-bit (NVIDIA) 
Godot 2.1.4
NVIDIA 1070 - driver 385.69,  


**Issue description:**
Display scaling via Viewport and 2D doesn't work correctly on game when the game is fullscreen (only when it is fullscreen) AND Windows Display Settings Scale is different than 100% (which is very common today for them to be set greater than 100%). The behavior works correctly on Linux and OSX. I even adjusted scaling on OSX and behavior is good, but on Windows the scale is incorrect. In debugging the problem I found that if I print the screen size and the viewport size, they match in all of the working cases. However, in the fullscreen Windows Display Scale > 100% case, the viewport is the native resolution of the screen (1920x1080), but the screen may be something smaller due to scaling. I suspect the viewport is not getting set correctly when Windows Display Scale is > 100% and the game is fullscreen. However the screen size is getting set correctly. Toggling the HIDPI settings doesn't make a difference either.

Hopefully I explained this well enough. I know the user can right-click the application and set properties > compatibility > ignore scaling as an option, but they shouldn't have to do this. I supplied a sample project (ScalingExample) and a video demonstrating the behavior (errordemo)

In the meantime I will try to adjust the viewport manually on startup.

**Steps to reproduce:**
**_Demonstrate fullscreen without display scaling works correctly_**
In Windows 10 set your project settings as follows:
- Fullscreen (true)
- Stretch Mode (2d or viewport - I used 2d for the example)
- Stretch Aspect (keep - I've also tried the others)
Run the application
The game should render correctly
Stop the game

**_Demonstrate no fullscreen and resizing works correctly_**
Open Windows Display Settings and make sure "Scale and Layout" is set to 100%.
Change Project Settings > Fullscreen > False
Run the application 
Resize your window, the application should render correctly at the correct scale.
Stop the game

**_Demonstrate no fullscreen and resizing with Desktop Display Scaling works correctly_**
Open Windows Display Settings and make sure "Scale and Layout" is > 100%
Make sure Project Settings > Fullscreen > False
Run the application
Run the application and resize the window
The application should render correctly.
Stop the game

**_Demonstrate Error Condition - fullscreen with Desktop Display Scaling renders incorrectly_**
Open Windows Display Settings and make sure "Scale and Layout" is > 100%
Change Project Settings > Fullscreen > True
Run the application
The graphics will be scaled much larger than they should be and may be off screen
Stop the game

**Link to minimal example project:**
[ScalingExample.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1347536/ScalingExample.zip)
[errordemo.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1347537/errordemo.zip)

data.title: doc_status.py Python 2.7 backwards compatibility & Windows support
data.body:
Because Python 2.7 is currently recommended for building, it is cumbersome that the `doc/tools/doc_status.py` script requires Python 3. (Besides, lots of Python 2.7 installs out there :))

This makes the script backwards-compatible so it runs on both Python 2.7 and Python 3.0

Additionally, color escape sequences are only used if the terminal may support them.

data.title: Selectable Children toggle for 3D
data.body:
**Godot version:** 3.0-alpha 99a464c

As mentioned in #11655, it would be great to have the Selectable Children toggle ported over to the 3D side. Right now you can sorta replicate this functionality in 3D by saving the branch to a scene and having it be instanced (with "Editable Children" disabled). This lets you click on any child element in the viewport to select the parent, as the Selectable Children does in 2D. It does the job, but having the toggle would be more convenient, and would make sense alongside plans to implement the Lock toggle in 3D (#4447).

data.title: Line2D Tile Texture mode not tiling correctly
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
On LinuxMint 
NVIDIA CORPORATION GK104 [GeForce GTX 770]
Driver nvidia-375.66
Built from Master

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
I've been experimenting with Line2D and noticed that applying texture with tiling didn't tile it at all. Instead it renders the texture shown once and then it renders the left side of the line like it does with  the None Texture Mode.

![skarmbild fran 2017-10-01 16-20-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7757419/31055531-8f6b7806-a6c4-11e7-9be3-ec408d9757c7.png)

Considering that you can do a lot more with tiled textures I would love to see it fixed.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a Line2D with some points
2. Add texture to a Line2D
3. Set Texture Mode to Tiled

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[Line2DProblem.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1347204/Line2DProblem.zip)

data.title: 3-D Platformer Demo: Internal Script Error - opcode #31 (report please)
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**

- Ubuntu Linux 17.04
- Godot 3.0 - (Latest Build from Git Head Master)
- NVIDIA Corporation GK106M [GeForce GTX 765M] (rev a1)

**Issue description:**

- running the 3-D Platformer Demo from https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects.git
- When player collides with coin receive the "opcode #31" error

**Steps to reproduce:**

- git clone  https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects.git/master
- git clone latest Godot 3.0 (commit d3345121ccf12eb5f11f4200b3b4ddc92823817c)
- build Godot 3.0 (`git pull upstream master; git clean -f; scons platform=x11 --clean; git push origin master; scons platform=x11`)
- open the godot-demo-projects/3d/platformer
- run it
- play until player hits a coin
- debugger activates and displays the opcode #31 error

![screenshot from 2017-10-01 10-35-50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1789892/31055879-b9ef3446-a697-11e7-8088-e63feed948e4.png)
![screenshot from 2017-10-01 10-36-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1789892/31055878-b9ee5af8-a697-11e7-802f-be465ccd4431.png)

data.title: OBJ import not working due to wrong importer being used
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7
Godot 3.0 built from master (today)

**Issue description:**
I was trying to import an OBJ into my project, but the imported version had no mesh data, and when it was selected, the import panel was displaying import options for "scene" not "OBJ"

I threw some print outs into the code to see what was happening, and it looks like when an OBJ is found without a .import file, it tries to find what importer to use based on it's extension. Since the scene importer plugin also returns .obj as an accepted file type, this is the importer that ends up being used instead of the OBJ importer. I'm guessing it's finding the scene importer and accepting it before it comes across the OBJ importer, so it might be a matter of re-ordering the list of importers. 

I commented out the following on line 4639 of editor_node.cpp:

`Ref<EditorOBJImporter> import_obj;`
`import_obj.instance();`
`import_scene->add_importer(import_obj);`

and it solved the problem for me, although I doubt this is the correct way to do it since the scene importer probably still needs to be able to handle obj stuff. I did try re-ordering the importers, but it didn't seem to make any difference, which surprised me. Still, I think commenting out the above code proves the area where the problem is occurring.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Save an OBJ file into your project folder
Once Godot has imported it, check the .import file it produced for it in the project directory
The .import file contains type="scene" instead of type="mesh" (a correctly imported OBJ import file should contain "importer="wavefront_obj")

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Add missing N.L factor to Burley's contribution to radiance.
data.body:
The thing that gets add to light_amount variable is f(L,V,N) (N.V), which is (normalized) BRDF multiplied by (N.V), which, after multiplying with incoming irradiance gives the radiance per solid angle.

Some of the variables here and there probably needs a rename to avoid such confusions...

We should probably take the N.V factor out of light_amount, rename it to diffuse_brdf, and multiply it by N.V at the end when calculating the radiance to be added to diffuse light to avoid any mistakes in the future.

Non-physical ones which can't be written in terms of a BRDF (meaning those which don't contribute to radiance in the form f(L,V,N) L_i (L) (N.V) d, such as toon) can be added to diffuse light directly

data.title: EditorAudioBus: restore delete option on master bus
data.body:
Related: #11569 #10215 

Fixes 'Reset Volume' being disabled on master bus instead of (nonexistent) 'Delete'.

IMO, I prefer disabling the option than hiding it so that users know popup contains 'Delete' option.
However, if we agree that it should be hidden, I'll remove the code that disables the option instead.

data.title: Add signal for when AnimationPlayer has processed an animation frame,
data.body:
There should be an equivalent of get_tree()'s "idle_frame" for the AnimationPlayer (or AnimationTreePlayer?), just when it has finished the update for the current frame. This would make it possible to override animation transformations during coroutines. At the moment, we can resume execution at what I assume is the start of each frame (idle_frame), but not the end. So an alternative to adding the signal to AnimationPlayer, could be to add a signal for when all objects have updated, something like "idle_frame_post".

Problem example:
```
func _start_cursor_aim_routine():
    var timer = 0
    var duration = 1
    var start_angle = some_obj.rotation_deg
    while timer < duration:
        var end_angle = rotation_towards_cursor
        timer += get_process_delta_time()
        some_obj.rotation_deg = lerp(start_angle, end_angle, timer/duration)
        yield(get_tree(), "idle_frame")
        [animation updates after each time this function resumes, thus overriding everything we do here :( ]
```

To work around it using booleans and _process() is a huge hassle, as it required me to create at least 8 class variables compared to only local variables

data.title: Fix GraphEdit mouse scroll axis.
data.body:
maps BUTTON_WHEEL_UP/DOWN to vscroll of GraphEdit.
maps KEY_SHIFT + BUTTON_WHEER_UP/DOWN to hscroll of GraphEdit.

This should fixes #11737 .

data.title: UI: LineEdit signal not firing issue
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows10 64bit

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

PROBLEM: When i try to use the focus_exit() signal under "LineEdit" guielement it never seems to fire, but the focus_enter() works just fine. NB: I tried all focus modes (ALL, NONE, CLICK).

It would also be nice if there were 2 methods like ReleaseFocus(), CaptureFocus() so we can set hotkeys when to capture focus on LineEdit guielement, im trying to make chat and and set hotkey for my chat, but there's no CaptureFocus() or equivelant method.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Click on "LineEdit" ttextbox and try to click away or press enter, it never looses focus and is stuck focused forever. NB: Changing Focus Mode between "All" and "Click" didn't change a thing.

<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Fix zoom button not zooming on the screen center
data.body: Fixes #11696

data.title: Update VS project generation
data.body:
Update VS project generation and add num_jobs option (default value: 2 - the same as before) for parallel builds inside Visual Studio. Tested with SCons 3.0 and Visual Studio 2017.
[Edit]
SCons 3.0 is necessary to create proper vsproject for Visual Studio 2017 toolchain (earlier SCons version doesn't detect VS 2017 batch file).
